you'll see their pictures in a few
slides
I'm also very lucky to work with my

a very fun experience and you can see us

Dyne and learned all about plasmonics

and I was an undergrad at a small

and I was a Chinese major from the start
so I wasn't convinced that I was
interested in chemistry when I started
college I was very interested in
languages but at a liberal arts school
you have a chance to explore lots of

I'm working on our mass spectrometer
with my adviser Deborah gross in the

convinced me to go on to graduate school
and go on in science um I was also very
fortunate to grow up next to a major

primarily in Madison Wisconsin and so
for those of you who have ever done any

really benefited from a law
of the outreach activities going on at

I'm doing something with polymers and I

the time which was it was impressive and
so as this elementary school student I
got interested in you know the colors of

chemistry can play a role that way and
maybe you can see from the kind of dorky
mid-90s glasses I was I was probably a
little bit of a nerd as an elementary
school student and so looking back there
were actually two things that I saw as a
student as a very young kid I'm then
influenced how I think about science
today so here's one of the things that I
remember as a kid this is a very old
movie it's called the powers of 10 made
in 1977 and I don't know if any of you
have actually seen this movie it has
over 5 million views on YouTube
so even many decades later people are
still watching this movie and what it
does is it starts with a picnic in
Chicago and then zooms out many orders
of magnitude to give you a sense of
scale and what different powers of 10
might be as you zoom out and then also
once we reach you know huge distances
they zoom back in and so in this video
they zoom into someone's hand and into
their cells and into their bodies and we
can see how the chemicals make up some
of these really important length scales
and so I thought this was a very cool
movie back when I was a kid something
else I really liked was this show the
Magic School Bus and it seems like some
of you may have seen this this show
involved this Magic School Bus and one
episode that I actually remember was
where they shrunk their school bus down
and put it in someone's body and you
could see the blood cells and the
different organs floating by and they
actually use their school bus then to go
in and cure some disease or something
and so so these are two things from my
childhood that kind of looking back
make me think about you know what if we
could actually zoom in many orders of
magnitude look at the surfaces of cells
look at molecules and proteins and how
they interact and how especially on the
nanometer length scale these systems
might be relevant for chemistry and the
reason I think that's really important
is a lot of the societal challenges that
we've heard about today do have a lot of
relationship to nanometer length scale
structure and dynamics so when we think
about harvesting clean energy a lot of
current photovoltaic systems use
nanometer scale domains in understanding
how charges travel through these
nanoscale domains is really critical to
understanding losses of efficiency and
thinking about ways to design better
solar cells when we think about human
health over 70% of currently marketed
pharmaceuticals target cell membrane
proteins in ourselves and actually we
don't have a very good idea of what is a
picture of a cell membrane and so we
know that cell membranes are very
crowded and they're very dynamic
heterogeneous environments but we don't
have a great understanding of how the
different local environments around a
given protein in this membrane might
affect the function of an event like
pharmaceutical binding i'm also we just
heard a lot about batteries if we want
to think about storing energy the
nanometer length scale is really
critical for understanding the flow of
charges in these systems and so as
chemists you know I think these are
problems that we should all be thinking
about tackling and this length scale on
being able to image on this nanometer
length scale and understand how local
environments affect function is really
crucial but one thing all of these
examples have in common is these
pictures are all still cartoons okay so
we're still at sort of this 1977 picture
of depicting some of these really
important processes with cartoons and
the reason why is because it's very hard
to image on this nanometer length scale
and so I was trained as a physical
chemist and so I have one equation on
the slide
but this equation is so important that
the person who developed it put it on
his tombstone so this is the abbe
diffraction limit and what it tells us
is that the the resolution that we can
achieve in a microscope depends on the
wavelength of light that we use to image
the system and the reason that there's
this fundamental limit to imaging
resolution just comes from the fact that
light has wave-like characteristics and
so if we're looking at point source is
emitting light the signal that we get is
wave-like and as we bring those point
sources together their signals start to
interact and we can no longer resolve
them and so this is known as the optical
diffraction limit and it's it's been
known for hundreds of years and it's a
fundamental limit of imaging and so with
an optical microscope we use visible
lights and so the diffraction limit
turns out to be about 250 nanometers and
so to give you an idea of that scale if
we think about a cell membrane that's
equivalent to probing about 400,000
lipid molecules in one
diffraction-limited spot and so if we
want to know how the local environment
around a given protein is affecting its
function we would be averaging out over
a huge number of different environments
using a light microscope if we think
about organic solar cells I which are
now four more three dimensional systems
the diffraction limit means we probe
approximately three million light
absorbing molecules in a solar cell and
so if we want to know what sort of
domains are ideal for making a good
solar cell in extracting the charges by
using normal microscopy we are averaging
out all of those different local domains
and so one question that I've been very
interested in is what if we could
actually beat this diffraction limit if
we could beat this this law that's
existed for hundreds hundreds of years
and understand how local environments
affect function and so this was a paper
that came out right when I was in
graduate school this is from Xiao Wei
drawings group here's a normal
microscope image of labeled microtubules
so she puts fluorescent molecules on
these microtubules and this is a
diffraction-limited image
so this is what we would see in a normal
microscope and what she and others have
developed is a class of techniques
called super resolution microscopy and
where we can actually beat the
diffraction limit and now assume in
another order of magnitude into living
systems and with super resolution
microscopy now you can take something
that would just be blurry with normal
microscopy and really resolve a whole
lot of fantastic structure these are
these crossing microtubules in this cell
and the individual dots that you see
that make up this picture are actually
individual fluorescent molecules and so
these class of techniques are I think
just amazing so super resolution
microscopy was awarded the Nobel Prize a
few years ago and there are three
different approaches that exist
currently in the literature and now we
can use these fluorescence base based
techniques to get down to the ten
nanometer length scale and start probing
some of these local structure function
problems however I think the the biggest
issue right now in super resolution
microscopy is that it's based on
fluorescence and so you need to actually
label your sample with these fluorescent
molecules in order to get a super
resolution image and one of the major
challenges with that is that
fluorophores bleach very quickly their
signal turns off very rapidly in the
matter of minutes depending on different
circumstances and that's very limiting
for the number of systems that we could
now look at on this 10 nanometer length
scale I mean so when I started my
faculty career I came up with an idea to
try and get super-resolution imaging
without the need for these fluorescent
labels so this is our idea it's a
technique based on Raman spectroscopy so
we use intrinsic spectroscopic signals
from molecules in this case there are
molecular vibrations in order to see
different molecules in let's say a cell
and so here now we don't need to use
external labels we would hope to get
super-resolution imaging without the
need for those labels and so just to
show you
what this type of research actually
looks like here's the picture of version
1.0 in my lab there is a normal
microscope here and then a complicated
laser table with lots of optics and so
what we've been working on is trying to
understand if it's possible to do
label-free sub diffraction imaging and I
probably wouldn't be standing here and
telling you about it if it didn't work
so we have been able to prove that this
label-free approach to super resolution
imaging does work how we can beat the
diffraction limit by about a factor of
two here we're looking across a glass
Diamond interface in order to
characterize the resolution in our
system and so now with this new tool
that we have I think that we can really
answer some of the questions that I
mentioned in the beginning to really
tackle some very important problems in
society so thinking about how local
environments can affect drug receptor
binding interactions I'm looking at
solar cells like bulk heterojunction
photovoltaics are looking at how how
charges transport across different
nanoscale interfaces and we can use what
we learned to then divide design more
efficient systems and so with that let
me thank my really fantastic group who's
been inspirational in getting this done
and we're passionate about Raman
spectroscopy here's a slang down with
our Raman theme and we are also very
interested in the colors of our samples
and spectroscopy so we have a rainbow
theme we've had a number of wonderful

after listening to me
